title: Storm Brewing Off Florida Coast Could Become Tropical Depression
message:
If it strengthens, it will be the second storm to affect the United States this season, following Hurricane Beryl, which struck Texas in early July.
The National Hurricane Center (NHC) is watching “a large tropical wave” that is set to enter the Caribbean on July 31, approaching the Lesser Antilles.
To become a tropical depression, this tropical wave would have to develop into a cyclone with “organized deep convection” and surface winds moving counter-clockwise around a “well-defined center,” producing maximum sustained winds of 38 mph or less, according to the NWS.
If the system takes shape, it will be introduced as Tropical Depression Debby.
Hurricane season began on June 1 and will run through Nov. 30.

title: Sand from the Sahara Desert causing recent lull in the hurricane season : scientists | iNFOnews
message:
Sand from the Sahara Desert causing recent lull in the hurricane season: scientistsScientists say tiny grains of sand from the Sahara Desert are to blame for the almost month-long lull in this year's Atlantic hurricane season.
THE CANADIAN PRESS/HO — Amanda Dunfield, *MANDATORY CREDIT*Original Publication Date July 31, 2024 - 1:01 AMHALIFAX - Tiny grains of sand from the Sahara Desert are to blame for the almost month-long lull in this year's Atlantic hurricane season, scientists say.
"You can see it in the atmosphere, moving from Africa westward across the Atlantic," says Chris Fogarty, manager of the Canadian Hurricane Centre in Dartmouth, N.S.
Fogarty, however, said hurricane season is sure to pick up in the weeks ahead, with the peak of the season typically arriving in the first few weeks of September.
In late May, the Canadian Hurricane Centre predicted an active hurricane season fuelled by record high ocean temperatures.

message:

It came exactly a year after a previous bout of severe flooding hit Vermont and several other states.

title: 2 years after Hurricane Ian , FEMA approves $2 million for Okeechobee County
message:
OKEECHOBEE COUNTY, Fla. — Nearly two years after a monster Hurricane Ian left a trail of damage in Okeechobee County, the federal government has approved a $2 million grant to reimburse the county for debris removal.
Ian, which at one point grew to Category 5 strength, hammered Florida in late September of 2022, downing trees, damaging roofs, and knocking out power to Okeechobee County residents.
WPTV Multiple mobile homes in Okeechobee County were damaged by Hurricane Ian's wrath.
In a news release Wednesday, the Federal Emergency Management Agency said it's approved a $2 million grant that will be reimbursed to the county to cover the costs of extensive debris cleanup.
"Approximately 180,868 cubic yards of vegetative debris and 4,796 cubic yards of hurricane-generated debris were removed from roads and public property," FEMA said.

title: 4 . 7 - magnitude earthquake jolts Tokyo area : JMA
message:
Tokyo, July 31 : An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 4.7 on early Wednesday rocked the Tokyo metropolitan area, the country's weather agency said.
The temblor occurred at 01:47 a.m. local time, measuring 3 on the Japanese seismic intensity scale of 7 in areas in Tokyo, Kanagawa and Chiba Prefecture, said the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA).
At a depth of 120 km, the epicentre was located in Tokyo's 23 wards at a latitude of 35.7 degrees north and a longitude of 139.6 degrees east, Xinhua news agency reported.
The tremors were felt strongly in central Tokyo, with no tsunami warnings issued.
There have been no reports of damage or casualties due to the temblor.

CenterPoint CEO Jason Wells acknowledged during a special Texas Senate committee hearing Monday that the utility company plans to pass its recovery costs onto its 2.8 million customers in the Houston area.

CenterPoint intends to increase their rates to recoup the cost of recovering from Hurricane Beryl, passing the cost on to the customer.

While there is no place on Earth that is immune to the impact of climate change, some places are less exposed to risk than others.
Note also that FEMA’s ratings consider not only the kinds of events that can be worsened by climate change (floods, droughts, wildfires, storms), but also natural hazards that aren’t affected by climate change, like earthquakes and volcanoes.

title: It makes absolutely no sense : Man with mold in condo denied Ian recovery help by county
message:

title: Foster + Partners unveils plan for rebuilding Antakya post - earthquake
message:
British architecture studio Foster + Partners has revealed its masterplan to rebuild Antakya, Turkey, following the Turkey-Syria earthquakes last year.
According to Foster + Partners, around 80 per cent of the buildings in Antakya were damaged in the earthquake.
"Before the earthquake, the city of Antakya faced some challenges that we aim to address during the sustainable reconstruction," said Foster + Partners partner Loukia Iliopoulou.
Foster + Partners plans to begin rebuilding in one area of Antakya, starting with building the high streets to establish homes near places of employment.
The images are by Foster + Partners.

title: Post - storm rebuilding costs could be issue for working - class Florida residents
message:
As the Atlantic Ocean shows signs of heating up, potentially fueling damaging hurricanes, a former state and national disaster chief warned Tuesday of working-class Floridians being priced out of communities in post-storm rebuilding.
“I don't think it's going to slow down rebuilding, because it's not really slowing things down in Fort Myers,” Fugate said, referring to rebuilding after Hurricane Ian slammed into the Fort Myers area in 2022.
“They're actually taking very smart, appropriate steps to address the issue of changing climate events,” Fugate said.
While it had not forecast rapid intensification, the hurricane center put Florida in the potential path of the system.
The chance of formation over the next week was upped from 50 percent on Monday to 60 percent Tuesday morning.

title: Political Spin : Irresponsible forest management spawns catastrophic fires
message:
A column by Bruce UzelmanJasper, Alberta is the latest community to experience catastrophic wildfire.
Forest management policies, beginning in the early 1900s, prioritized fire suppression to preserve valuable timber and reforestation with the most commercially valuable species, which were coniferous, particularly pine.
The disastrous fire at Jasper demonstrates the impact of past and present forest management.
B.C.’s Forest Practices Board recommends “landscape forest management,” to provide protection against aggressive wildfire.
Rather, without extensive reform, Jasper is the first of many catastrophic wildfires that will befall Canada’s west in 2024 and beyond.

title: Governor signs bill allocating $100M to Ruidoso wildfire recovery
message:
SANTA FE, N.M. (KRQE) – Governor Michelle Lujan Grisham has signed the only legislation to come out of her recent special session.
The bill, passed by lawmakers earlier this month, puts $100 million toward the wildfire response in the Ruidoso area.
New Mexico lawmakers hear talk on AI technology, transparency measuresThe governor originally called the special session to address crime.
Amid criticism from the governor’s fellow Democrats, lawmakers adjourned the session without taking up any issues besides the Ruidos disaster recovery.
For the latest news, weather, sports, and streaming video, head to KRQE NEWS 13 - Breaking News, Albuquerque News, New Mexico News, Weather, and Videos.

title: NC county emergency services reminds folks to  plan  as chances up to 60 % for tropical development
message:
NC county emergency services reminds folks to ‘plan’ as chances up to 60% for tropical developmentCLINTON, N.C. (WNCN) — One central North Carolina county is already encouraging residents to get ready as the chances for a tropical system developing increased again on Tuesday.
Soon after that message went out, Sampson County Emergency Services forwarded it out on a social media post.
The Clinton Police Department also shared the social media post from emergency services.
Officials with the Sampson County Emergency Services are asking people to think about a plan for “you and your family” if the system heads to North Carolina.
Sampson County Emergency Services also encouraged residents to sign up for alerts from the county.

title: BMKG : Magnitude 5 . 0 Earthquake Jolts Maluku , No Tsunami Threat
message:
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Indonesia's Meteorology, Climatology, and Geophysics Agency (BMKG) reported that a magnitude 5.0 earthquake struck the east coast of Central Maluku on Wednesday, July 31, 2024, at 6:21 a.m. local time.
The source mechanism analysis shows that the quake had a strike-slip mechanism,” said Daryono, the agency’s head of the quake and tsunami center, on Wednesday, July 31.
Tremors were felt in Central and Southwest Maluku, reaching an intensity of III on the Modified Mercalli Intensity (MMI) scale.
No damages or casualties have been reported, and the BMKG has issued no tsunami warning.
The public is advised to remain calm, not be influenced by baseless issues, and avoid cracked or damaged buildings.

title: Vermont man evacuates neighbors during flooding , weeks after seeing driver get swept away
message:
Weeks after Jason Pilbin witnessed a driver get swept away by floodwaters, his northeastern Vermont community was ravaged again by flooding from heavy rains.
Nearly three weeks ago, he watched helplessly as a man drowned after getting caught while driving through floodwaters from Hurricane Beryl.
More rain was forecast for central and northern Vermont on Wednesday, with the possibility of flash flooding.
The fresh flooding yielded similar scenes of catastrophe as the flooding weeks earlier in which two people died, but on a smaller scale.
It came exactly a year after a previous bout of severe flooding hit Vermont and several other states.

title: California Park Fire could burn for weeks or months
message:
Experts are warning that the Park Fire could continue to spread for weeks, if not months and has the potential to become the biggest California wildfire ever.
June was the 13th consecutive month to break a global heat record.
Some areas of the burn had their single-hottest 30-day periods on record just before the Park Fire broke out.
David Peterson, a meteorologist at the United States Naval Research Laboratory in Monterey, California told the Times that fire-generated storms will impede fire-fighting.
The exceptionally hot and dry conditions are making for a record wildfire season on the West Coast.

This map shows how much rain needs to fall in one hour to produce flash flooding.
Parts of northeast Vermont and New Hampshire may only need to see 1 inch an hour to get flash flooding.

message:

title: Tropical system strengthening in the Atlantic . Will it mean a hurricane for Hilton Head ?
message:
Tropical system strengthening in the Atlantic.
A tropical disturbance in the mid-Atlantic is steadily increasing its likelihood of developing into a tropical depression, according to the National Hurricane Center.
A tropical disturbance becomes a tropical depression when the storm has maximum sustained surface winds of 38 mph or less.
Some models suggest the system could pass near Florida’s east coast over the weekend as a tropical depression or tropical storm, according to reporting by the Miami Herald.
If the disturbance develops into a tropical storm, it would be called Debby.

title: 4 . 7 - magnitude earthquake jolts Tokyo area : JMA - Xinhua
message:
TOKYO, July 31 (Xinhua) -- An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 4.7 on early Wednesday rocked the Tokyo metropolitan area, the country's weather agency said.
The temblor occurred at 01:47 a.m. local time, measuring 3 on the Japanese seismic intensity scale of 7 in areas in Tokyo, Kanagawa and Chiba Prefecture, said the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA).
At a depth of 120 km, the epicenter was located in Tokyo's 23 wards at a latitude of 35.7 degrees north and a longitude of 139.6 degrees east.
The tremors were felt strongly in central Tokyo, with no tsunami warnings issued.
There have been no reports of damage or casualties due to the temblor.

title: Eastern Pacific Basin Roars to Life
message:
31 Jul 2024 11:15 AMThere are multiple areas of potential tropical formation in the Eastern Pacific ranging from a low to high chance of formation in the next 7 days, including two areas of HIGH likelihood of development off the western coast of Mexico.
The area of low pressure with the highest likelihood of formation has been named "Invest 94-E" by the National Hurricane Center and "a tropical depression is very likely to form within the next couple of days.
The system is forecast to move westward to west-northwestward at 10 to 15 mph during the next several days, remaining offshore of the southern coast of Mexico."
Right now, this is NO threat to land, but will likely create large swells from the Baja through central Mexico.
If it manages to reach Tropical Storm Strength, it will be Caroletta.

title: Tropical depression or storm may form by this weekend

title: Tropical depression could form near Florida this weekend , NHC says
message:
A large tropical wave in the Caribbean could develop into a tropical depression near Florida or the Bahamas as early as the end of this week or this weekend, according to a Wednesday morning update from the National Hurricane Center.
Environmental conditions in this area are favorable for development as the tropical wave moves toward the west-northwest over the Greater Antilles and the Bahamas, forecasters said.
Should it develop into anything stronger than a tropical depression, the next storm name on tap for the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season is Debby.
"In this scenario, if you hadn't been watching the weather, you may never know a tropical depression or tropical storm was tracking offshore of Florida toward the Carolinas," Garner said.
As the dust's influence wanes this weekend, there will be a window for the disturbance to develop into a tropical depression, or maybe Tropical Storm Debby.

title: How stormwater can impact our waterways
message:
LEXINGTON, Ky. (WKYT)—In 2006, the EPA and the Commonwealth sued the City of Lexington, saying that the city failed to properly manage stormwater.
After a system overhaul and some hard work, Lexington won a national award for stormwater mitigation and management in 2018.
When we get rain here in Kentucky, we get stormwater, excess water runoff that doesn’t soak into the ground after a storm.
However, during periods of excessive rainfall, new concerns can arise about stormwater mitigation efforts.
Unlike our sanitary sewer system, stormwater runoff is not treated but discharged directly into our creeks and streams, along with the pollutants it grabbed along the way.

title: Extreme heat to linger in southeast Louisiana for several more days
message:

title: Storms wreak havoc on Southeast US leaving 1 dead and thousands without power
message:

No one was injured along the path of the storm, which stayed on the ground for 3.4 miles (5.4 kilometers).

title: Of little to no use : Texas Lt . Governor wants CenterPoint to pay for generators funded by ratepayers
message:
Governor Dan Patrick criticized CenterPoint Energy for leasing massive ratepayer funded generators instead of mobile generators which could be used more effectively in emergency situations.
“There were many questions about CenterPoint’s controversial lease of massive generators that could not be quickly used as mobile generators as intended in Senate Bill 1075 and House Bill 1500 (88th Legislative Session).
Those bills allowed companies like CenterPoint and Oncor to lease small mobile generators to quickly get power to hospitals, vulnerable populations, and cooling/warming centers,” Patrick said.
Oncor and similar companies followed the legislation and obtained small mobile generators for emergencies, as was the intent of the legislation, and have deployed them appropriately.
Patrick is now calling for the Public Utility Commission to make CenterPoint pay for the generators using company profits instead.
